meta.title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
meta.author: Merlin Sheldrake

parts.title: The Fascinating World of Fungi
parts.body:
A Fascination with Fungi

In a lush canopy alive with toucans and howler monkeys, Merlin Sheldrake examines tree roots and embarks on uncovering a hidden fungal world. He observes a complex web of fungal networks that support life, making insights about the crucial role fungi play in ecosystems. Sheldrake marvels at fungi's ability to break down difficult substances, prompting thoughts on their potential in modern challenges. Through a scientific lens, he drafts a captivating narrative about fungi’s vast influence on land and life.

parts.title: Complexity of Truffles and Fungi
parts.body: Truffles have a fascinating interaction with their environment. 1. Unique Growth: The blue line of paint illustrates hyphal growth. Hyphae grow by getting longer, much like a continuous stream of paint—a map of a fungus’s history. 2. Amazing Strength: Hyphal tips exert pressure that can lift an 8-ton school bus, showing how fungi can break tough barriers. Mushrooms, appearing after rain, contain water to generate explosive force. 3. Mysterious Coordination: What the spontaneous wave in Olsson's experiment implies remains unknown. Mycelium acts as one organism, suggesting communication across the network. In a world of chemical call-and-response, truffles display richness and complexity, continuously shaping their unpredictable environment.

parts.title: Fascinating Lichens and Mycelium Networks
parts.body: Lichens are fascinating creatures that cover a large part of the Earth's surface, thriving in places like rocks, trees, and even deserts. These organisms, appearing as shrubs, antlers, or hashtags, are known for their colorful forms and sometimes camouflage beetles. Lichens are partly composed of a fungus and an alga working together: the fungus provides protection and nutrients, while the alga converts light into energy. This symbiotic relationship allows them to survive in harsh environments, making them a model for astrobiological research. The concept of mycelium, a complex network of fungi, is instrumental in understanding lichens. Mycelium helps fungi reproduce and communicate, akin to brain-like networks. Through symbiosis, lichen and mycelium exemplify the occurrence of horizontal gene transfer, where organisms acquire new traits from others. This phenomenon changes our perception of life's complexity and expands our understanding of inter-kingdom collaboration, challenging traditional concepts like the tree of life and how species evolve and adapt.

parts.title: Psychedelics and Zombie Fungi
parts.body: LSD and psilocybin are psychedelics that cause significant changes in perception, including visual hallucinations and a feeling of unity with the world. Many users report experiencing a loss of identity and a connection with the divine. Measuring such experiences using psychometric questionnaires can be challenging because the sensation of timelessness and oneness with reality are qualitative, not quantitative states. "Zombie fungi" like Ophiocordyceps unilateralis infect insects, notably ants, and control their actions with amazing precision, compelling them to climb plants and perform a "death grip" in optimal conditions for the fungus’s spores to spread. This process does not involve the fungal presence in the ant's brain but likely relies on chemical means to alter ant behavior. This showcases fungi's unmatched precision in influencing behavior, unlike the broad and clumsy effects of human-manipulated drugs.

parts.title: Role of Mycorrhizal Networks in Ecosystems
parts.body: The complexity of mycorrhizal networks and their role in ecosystems is intricate. Fungal networks are more than just channels connecting plants; they are active entities capable of solving spatial problems and actively managing nutrient transport. Research by Toby Kiers shows that fungi don't just passively facilitate connections between plants—they engage in sophisticated trading strategies. For instance, fungi can decide how to allocate nutrients like phosphorus, favoring certain plants over others depending on the conditions and their own needs. This dynamic management of resources reflects a complex relationship within ecosystems that relies heavily on the balance between mutualism and competition.

parts.title: Fungal Networks and Forest Webs
parts.body: In the Wood Wide Web and mycorrhizal networks, older hub trees are crucial to forest communication and nutrient sharing—similar to how the internet has key nodes like Google and Amazon. This scale-free network makes forests resilient but also vulnerable to logging, as cutting down large trees is like shutting down major websites. This concept extends to indigenous metaphorical thinking about the mycelium as a sort of nervous system of the forest. However, more research is needed to understand varying global mycorrhizal architectures. Intriguingly, wood wide webs and networks resemble complex adaptive systems like brains or cities, suggesting that forests self-organize dynamically. Such systems adapt with interactions far beyond a straightforward cause-effect—similar to financial markets or the internet—where small stimuli can trigger large systemic responses. There is potential for fungal networks to be explored further without solely relying on human metaphors of neuroplasticity or internet analogies, letting them reveal unique properties and processes in ecosystems.

parts.title: Human Values in Symbiosis
parts.body: Humans often project their values onto nature, such as symbiosis, where organisms live together. The concept reflects societal norms and debates whether nature is more competitive or cooperative. Narratives of evolution and biology heavily rely on metaphors which bring baggage. For instance, fungal networks are compared to socialism or markets, where nutrients may be traded or shared like in an economy. These metaphors help shape how we perceive the natural world but also have limitations.

parts.title: Brain and Fungal Symbiosis Insights
parts.body: The interconnection between networks of brain activity during normal waking consciousness and after an injection of psilocybin can show dramatic differences. Psilocybin creates a storm of new neuronal pathways, showcasing its potential to change mind states due to these cerebral fluxes. This display was based on a study by Petri, et al. (2014), emphasizing how psilocybin affects our brains at a foundational level. The roots of the mycoheterotroph Voyria tenella are densely populated by mycorrhizal fungi, which form light-colored rings around the plant's root edge. When examined closely (depicted in red), these fungal associations reveal a narrow world where plant and fungi exchange nutrients. These intimate connections underline the complex symbiosis that occurs between plants and fungi, illustrating "intimacies within intimacies" as depicted by Sheldrake et al. (2017).

parts.title: Plants, Fungi and Mycorrhizal Connections
parts.body: Plants and Anthropomorphism: Debates about anthropomorphism in biology focus on how plants sense and respond to environments. In 2007, 36 plant scientists dismissed "plant neurobiology," arguing that plants’ signaling systems aren’t like humans or animals, sparking an ongoing discussion about anthropomorphism. Fungi and Mycelial Connections: Shared mycorrhizal networks link plants together, like Simard's study showing carbon movement between trees. Networks like these could play a vital role in ecosystems by enhancing seedling growth, redistributing nutrients, and modifying plant competition. These networks resemble the complexity of the World Wide Web, highlighting the intricate connections within ecosystems.

parts.title: Ectomycorrhizal Trees and Innovative Biology Approaches
parts.body: The association of ectomycorrhizal trees with high carbon-to-nitrogen ratio soils in temperate forests is primarily driven by smaller nitrogen details, as explained by Zhu et al. (2018). These trees are vital for ecological balance and biodiversity by controlling nutrient exchange. Additionally, Zhu et al. (2013) explore the amoeba-based computing of Physarum polycephalum for solving the traveling salesman problem, showing long-term correlations across spatially separated cells for innovative problem-solving. Merlin Sheldrake, a biologist and writer, brings new insights in his book '*Entangled Life*', delving into fungal networks and tropical ecology. His unique background in music and fermentation adds a multidimensional approach to his studies on fungi, emphasizing their integral role in ecosystem functioning, as showcased in Panama's rich underworld of tropical forests.
